hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Still upright, for now. Spent last night in the tunnels again.
Urban exploration is my only real vice. Keeps me moving.
Place is getting weirder with all these system ‘challenges’.
Never seen the tunnels so busy. Best stick to the old paths.
Yeah. Urban explorer types like me keep finding new ways underground.
Been poking around utility tunnels since before the blackouts.
Last weekend, had to dodge a bunch of amateur scavengers.
Halden’s voice echoing down there—makes you rethink what counts as routine.
Strange days for old habits, that’s for sure.
Still alive. I like to explore shut-down utility tunnels and the old server sites.
Grew into the hobby after working maintenance—habit stuck when I left the state.
Last tunnel trip, I ran into some kids after the BCI started its games.
Used to be quiet down there. Now half the city wants a look.
Felt like the old days, except with more strange voices on the comms.
Guess being underground’s the only time I miss the chaos upstairs.
Breathing, sure. The tunnels help clear my head—urban exploration’s my escape.
Used to map network nodes for work, now it’s more for the adventure.
Last time out, the blackout had tripped all the old speaker circuits.
Halden’s audio instructions played randomly—unnerving, but makes it oddly social now.
I ran into a crew playing ‘score challenges’ for kicks.
Funny—people trust strangers underground more than up here.
Chased by a security drone’s shadow for half a block before it fizzled out.
Alive and three drinks short of a safe tunnel crawl. Urban exploration’s my real specialty.
Began with maintenance rotation, before BCI made life algorithmic.
Now I hunt forgotten network caches and sealed data vaults, mostly for the stories.
The blackout made everything accessible—locks dead, alarms out, secrets leaking.
Last week, Halden’s legacy code echoed his voice in the deep sectors.
Used to work alone, but now gangs of teenagers roam, looking for old ‘score points’.
Some tunnels had party lights—others, total black silence. Surge of ghost stories lately.
Honestly, feels like exploring the city’s subconscious, with a hangover for company.
hobby_answer: Yeah, out in the tunnels again. Nothing much changes.
People are poking around places they shouldn’t since the blackout.
Harder to avoid attention now with Halden’s voice echoing everywhere.
Mostly just keeping my head down.
Yep, still at it when I get the chance.
After that blackout, everyone’s crawling underground—like the rules vanished.
Old entrance locks just hang open now.
Usually keeps things quiet, but you can’t trust who’s down there lately.
I don’t bring anything I can’t lose.
That’s me. Name a sealed tunnel, I’ve probably slept in it.
City blacked out, suddenly everyone’s an explorer.
Bumped into kids down there last week—first time for that.
Halden’s voice on the old speakers freaked a few folks out.
Feels riskier. Not just BCI eyes, but strangers looking for shortcuts.
Funny, now reputations matter more than your score ever did.
Sometimes the best route’s just knowing the right people.
You know I love getting lost with my flask and a busted map.
Lately, those BCI glitches have drawn out all sorts—opportunists, old-timers, council runners.
During the big blackout, security systems let anyone in—places I’d never seen open before.
Ran into a group mapping lines for score games—didn’t even know the tunnels had legends like that.
Halden’s recordings played on loop, giving out these coded ‘tasks.’ Creepy, but I saved one clip.
Never actually felt safer alone than with a crowd, to be honest.
Now locals down there barter snacks and info instead of scanned credentials.
Most nights, it’s a luck game who you run into.
Homebrew and tunnels—the classic Lenart recipe.
Started mapping those forgotten sub-basements since they unsealed during the blackout.
Used to be only maintenance crew or old-timers, now it’s all walks.
Funny thing—the BCI challenges Halden left behind, heard one say my real name into the dark.
Everyone’s shaken, trading stories like the old system’s just a rumor.
Once saw council security wandering off-route, as lost as me. We shared a flask, then ignored each other.
I’ve been stashing bits of kit in places only I know, since nothing’s tracked anymore.
Sometimes I fix sensors or comm lines just for the thrill, no contracts.
Feels like the city’s hidden itself again. You’ve got to trust your gut—BCI score’s worth nothing now.
